channel.title: Freakonomics Radio
channel.description: Discover the hidden side of everything with Stephen J. Dubner, co-author of the Freakonomics books. Each week, Freakonomics Radio tells you things you always thought you knew (but didn’t) and things you never thought you wanted to know (but do) — from the economics of sleep to how to become great at just about anything. Dubner speaks with Nobel laureates and provocateurs, intellectuals and entrepreneurs, and various other underachievers. Special features include series like “The Secret Life of a C.E.O.” as well as a live game show, “Tell Me Something I Don’t Know.”
channel.itunes:author: ​Dubner Productions and Stitcher
channel.itunes:summary: Discover the hidden side of everything with Stephen J. Dubner, co-author of the Freakonomics books. Each week, Freakonomics Radio tells you things you always thought you knew (but didn’t) and things you never thought you wanted to know (but do) — from the economics of sleep to how to become great at just about anything. Dubner speaks with Nobel laureates and provocateurs, intellectuals and entrepreneurs, and various other underachievers. Special features include series like “The Secret Life of a C.E.O.” as well as a live game show, “Tell Me Something I Don’t Know.”

item.title: 391. America’s Math Curriculum Doesn’t Add Up
item.description: Most high-school math classes are still preparing students for the Sputnik era. Steve Levitt wants to get rid of the “geometry sandwich” and instead have kids learn what they really need in the modern era: data fluency.
item.itunes:title: America’s Math Curriculum Doesn’t Add Up
item.itunes:summary: Most high-school math classes are still preparing students for the Sputnik era. Steve Levitt wants to get rid of the “geometry sandwich” and instead have kids learn what they really need in the modern era: data fluency.
item.content:encoded: Most high-school math classes are still preparing students for the Sputnik era. Steve Levitt wants to get rid of the “geometry sandwich” and instead have kids learn what they really need in the modern era: data fluency.
item.itunes:keywords: steve levitt,Dubner Productions,stitcher,stephen j. dubner,freakonomics radio,math

item.title: 390. Fed Up
item.description: Mary Daly rose from high-school dropout to president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. She thinks the central bank needs an upgrade too. It starts with recognizing that the economy is made up of actual humans.
item.itunes:title: Fed Up
item.itunes:summary: Mary Daly rose from high-school dropout to president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. She thinks the central bank needs an upgrade too. It starts with recognizing that the economy is made up of actual humans.
item.content:encoded: Mary Daly rose from high-school dropout to president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. She thinks the central bank needs an upgrade too. It starts with recognizing that the economy is made up of actual humans.
item.itunes:keywords: Mary Daly,The Federal Reserve,Dubner Productions,stitcher,stephen j. dubner,Freakonomics Radio

item.title: 389. How to Make Meetings Less Terrible
item.description: In the U.S. alone, we hold 55 million meetings a day. Most of them are woefully unproductive, and tyrannize our offices. The revolution begins now — with better agendas, smaller invite lists, and an embrace of healthy conflict.
item.itunes:title: How to Make Meetings Less Terrible
item.itunes:summary: In the U.S. alone, we hold 55 million meetings a day. Most of them are woefully unproductive, and tyrannize our offices. The revolution begins now — with better agendas, smaller invite lists, and an embrace of healthy conflict.
item.content:encoded: In the U.S. alone, we hold 55 million meetings a day. Most of them are woefully unproductive, and tyrannize our offices. The revolution begins now — with better agendas, smaller invite lists, and an embrace of healthy conflict.

item.title: 358. Yes, the Open Office Is Terrible — But It Doesn’t Have to Be (Rebroadcast)
item.description: It began as a post-war dream for a more collaborative and egalitarian workplace. It has evolved into a nightmare of noise and discomfort. Can the open office be saved, or should we all just be working from home?
item.itunes:title: Yes, the Open Office Is Terrible — But It Doesn’t Have to Be (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:summary: It began as a post-war dream for a more collaborative and egalitarian workplace. It has evolved into a nightmare of noise and discomfort. Can the open office be saved, or should we all just be working from home?
item.content:encoded: It began as a post-war dream for a more collaborative and egalitarian workplace. It has evolved into a nightmare of noise and discomfort. Can the open office be saved, or should we all just be working from home?
item.itunes:keywords: Dubner Productions,stitcher,stephen j. dubner,freakonomics radio,open offices

item.title: 388. The Economics of Sports Gambling
item.description: What happens when tens of millions of fantasy-sports players are suddenly able to bet real money on real games? We’re about to find out. A recent Supreme Court decision has cleared the way to bring an estimated $300 billion in black-market sports betting into the light. We sort out the winners and losers.
item.itunes:title: The Economics of Sports Gambling
item.itunes:summary: What happens when tens of millions of fantasy-sports players are suddenly able to bet real money on real games? We’re about to find out. A recent Supreme Court decision has cleared the way to bring an estimated $300 billion in black-market sports betting into the light. We sort out the winners and losers.

item.itunes:keywords: Dubner Productions,stitcher,stephen j. dubner,freakonomics radio,Fantasy Sports,Sports Gambling

item.title: 367. The Future of Meat (Rebroadcast)
item.description: Global demand for beef, chicken, and pork continues to rise. So do concerns about environmental and other costs. Will reconciling these two forces be possible — or, even better, Impossible™?
item.itunes:title: The Future of Meat (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:summary: Global demand for beef, chicken, and pork continues to rise. So do concerns about environmental and other costs. Will reconciling these two forces be possible — or, even better, Impossible™?
item.content:encoded: Global demand for beef, chicken, and pork continues to rise. So do concerns about environmental and other costs. Will reconciling these two forces be possible — or, even better, Impossible™?
item.itunes:keywords: Dubner Productions,stitcher,stephen j. dubner,freakonomics radio,meat,Impossible Burger

item.title: 359. Should America Be Run by … Trader Joe’s? (Rebroadcast)
item.description: The quirky little grocery chain with California roots and German ownership has a lot to teach all of us about choice architecture, efficiency, frugality, collaboration, and team spirit.
item.itunes:title: Should America Be Run by … Trader Joe’s? (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:summary: The quirky little grocery chain with California roots and German ownership has a lot to teach all of us about choice architecture, efficiency, frugality, collaboration, and team spirit.
item.content:encoded: The quirky little grocery chain with California roots and German ownership has a lot to teach all of us about choice architecture, efficiency, frugality, collaboration, and team spirit.
item.itunes:keywords: Dubner Productions,stitcher,stephen j. dubner,freakonomics radio,Trader Joe's

item.title: 387. Hello, My Name Is Marijuana Pepsi!
item.description: Research shows that having a distinctively black name doesn’t affect your economic future. But what is the day-to-day reality of living with such a name? Marijuana Pepsi Vandyck, a newly-minted Ph.D., is well-qualified to answer this question. Her verdict: the data don’t tell the whole story.
item.itunes:title: Hello, My Name Is Marijuana Pepsi!
item.itunes:summary: Research shows that having a distinctively black name doesn’t affect your economic future. But what is the day-to-day reality of living with such a name? item.title: 122. How Much Does Your Name Matter? (Rebroadcast)
item.description: A kid’s name can tell us something about his parents — their race, social standing, even their politics. But is your name really your destiny?
item.itunes:title: How Much Does Your Name Matter? (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:summary: A kid’s name can tell us something about his parents — their race, social standing, even their politics. But is your name really your destiny?
item.content:encoded: A kid’s name can tell us something about his parents — their race, social standing, even their politics. But is your name really your destiny?
item.itunes:keywords: Dubner Productions,stitcher,stephen j. dubner,freakonomics radio,baby names

item.title: 386. How the Supermarket Helped America Win the Cold War
item.description: Aisle upon aisle of fresh produce, cheap meat, and sugary cereal — a delicious embodiment of free-market capitalism, right? Not quite. The supermarket was in fact the endpoint of the U.S. government’s battle for agricultural abundance against the U.S.S.R. Our farm policies were built to dominate, not necessarily to nourish — and we are still living with the consequences.
item.itunes:title: How the Supermarket Helped America Win the Cold War

item.title: 356. America’s Hidden Duopoly (Rebroadcast)
item.description: We all know our political system is “broken” — but what if that’s not true? Some say the Republicans and Democrats constitute a wildly successful industry that has colluded to kill off competition, stifle reform, and drive the country apart. So what are you going to do about it?
item.itunes:title: America’s Hidden Duopoly (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:summary: We all know our political system is “broken” — but what if that’s not true? Some say the Republicans and Democrats constitute a wildly successful industry that has colluded to kill off competition, stifle reform, and drive the country apart. So what are you going to do about it?
item.content:encoded: We all know our political system is “broken” — but what if that’s not true? Some say the Republicans and Democrats constitute a wildly successful industry that has colluded to kill off competition, stifle reform, and drive the country apart. So what are you going to do about it?

item.title: 385. What Do Nancy Pelosi, Taylor Swift, and Serena Williams Have in Common?
item.description: They — along with a great many other high-achieving women — were all once Girl Scouts. So was Sylvia Acevedo. Raised in a poor, immigrant family, she was told that “girls like her” didn’t go to college. But she did, and then became a rocket scientist and tech executive. Now she’s C.E.O. of the very organization she credits with shaping her life. Acevedo tells us how the Girl Scouts are trying to stay relevant, why they’re suing the Boy Scouts, and how they sell so many cookies.

item.title: 384. Abortion and Crime, Revisited
item.description: The controversial theory linking Roe v. Wade to a massive crime drop is back in the spotlight as several states introduce abortion restrictions. Steve Levitt and John Donohue discuss their original research, the challenges to its legitimacy, and their updated analysis. Also: what this means for abortion policy, crime policy, and having intelligent conversations about contentious topics.
item.itunes:title: Abortion and Crime, Revisited
item.itunes:summary: The controversial theory linking Roe v. Wade to a massive crime drop is back in the spotlight as several states introduce abortion restrictions.
